channel.title: David Keck
channel.description: Software developer with a passion for learning. Posting what inspires me and a few brain dumps.

item.title: There are no rules.
item.description:
Business lessons from someone with no experience in business

Recently, and, likely because I just graduated, I’ve been hearing dubious business advice like crazy. Stuff like “Don’t show your weaknesses”, and “Pretend to know everything.”

I’m sure it’s all well meaning, but, to me, it’s all garbage. It might be fine if you want to get a job under false pretenses or plan on getting a position that isn’t right for you or your employer.

If I don’t know a certain technology and I get asked about it in an interview, I always say directly that I don’t know anything about that, but I would be willing to learn. And, that’s only if I’m actually interested in learning it.

I want to expose my ignorance. Then I get to learn. If I come into a job acting like I know all about everything, I don’t get that chance.

You might be thinking, this guy has no idea about the “real-world” job market. And, you would be right! I think my naiveté and optimism will to serve me well. I don’t have to lie or feel pressured to perform in something I’ve never even given myself a chance to learn. I’m not disenchanted, and I can bring passion along with programming skills.

And, you know, I might not get the job that I thought I wanted. But that’s fine too. I have the luxury right now of being able to say no and accepting when companies do the same. I don’t have a family to support or any expenses that a minimum wage job couldn’t float for at least a few years.

I just know I would be much happier working at a Starbucks than under the thumb of some corporation that strangles my spirit.

You have to protect your spark of optimism and hope with everything you have. Too many people give up too soon or think that these are just the rules of the business world.

There are no rules. Do what makes sense to you.

Comments?

Email me.

item.title: "Anything You Want" - Book review
item.description:
I had the chance to read this book about a week ago. I expected to just read the first few pages before heading into work, but I found it so enthralling that I read the whole thing that morning. It only took about an hour, just like Derek said it would in the first chapter.

As you can tell, this book is pretty short. The content feels almost obsessively pared down to the most relevant message possible.

I love this book is because its voice is so lucid. Everything was so clear and easy to follow.

The chapters of the book are just dripping with understanding. Each scenario offers a chance to see a new perspective and step back from what might be considered “common sense” to illuminate an important insight that was made.

At the end of the book, Sivers invites anyone who has “made it this far” to email him with any comments or questions. I took advantage of this offer and I received an email back the very next day. It is obvious he cares about his readers, and it was nice to know that Sivers embodies the qualities he discusses in this book.

I feel like I learned a lot, and I definitely laughed a lot, but the most important thing I experienced from reading this book was an overwhelming sense of optimism and empowerment.

Rating: 10/10

Comments?

Email me.

item.title: Hello.
item.description:
Who are you?

I’m David Keck. I just graduated this May with a Bachelor of Computer Science. I love computers, and I started programming when I was about twelve or thirteen in BASIC. Currently, I’m working at NASA as an intern, making flight software for an in-development satellite.

What is this site?

This is my personal website where I’ll be posting information about my projects, thoughts, and ideas. I’ll also be linking to anything I find interesting with “Link Love” posts every now and then. (Thanks for the idea, Mark Sisson.) You can also view website source on github.

How can I contact you?

As you may have noticed, this website is lacking a comment section. This was partially intentional, and also partially because I am just learning the art of web design. If you have any comments or questions about anything you see on this website, feel free to email me. Use the title of the post as the email subject so I can better respond.

What’s your favorite color?

Single favorite? Dark blue.

Favorite combination? Dark green and dark grey.

Comments?

Email me.
